Mike McGrath, attorney general for the state of Montana, joined us by phone from his office in Helena.
To get a better sense of where the battle over medical marijuana is headed, we're going to speak with advocates on both sides.
First, we'll go to a proponent of medical marijuana.
Robert Raich was lead attorney on the Gonzales vs. Raich case, which the Supreme Court ruled on yesterday.
His wife Angel was one of the plaintiffs in that case.
He joins us now from a studio at the University of California at Berkeley.
Good of you to be with us today on TALK OF THE NATION.
It's my pleasure to be here.
How big a loss was yesterday's ruling?
No.
Well, yesterday's ruling really just preserves the status quo that existed the day before we ever filed that lawsuit.
The federal government claims that medical cannabis is illegal, and the state law continues to protect patients in California and the 11 other states with laws that protect patients.
So really, nothing has changed that way.
By filing this lawsuit, we had much to gain, but nothing to lose.
Well, as Attorney General McGrath just told us from Montana, there's certainly going to be a chilling effect.
People may not want to risk being arrested by the DEA.
That was always a right the DEA claimed it had all along.
Of course, it is a question.

Does the federal government want to squander its resources on patients who are trying to do nothing better than keep themselves healthy or alive, or should it be fighting terrorists and using its resources other ways?

That's something for the federal government, but I think it's clear the people of this country overwhelmingly support the obvious notion that patients deserve the right to have the medicine that keeps them healthy.
Every single poll has shown that between 70 and 80 percent of the American people support medical cannabis.
Where do you go from here?
Well, the next step is Congress.

The Supreme Court yesterday, in the final paragraph of its majority opinion, essentially called on Congress to change these laws, and as you mentioned, there is an opportunity as early as next week in the House of Representatives for Congress to do just that.

Representatives Hinchey and Rohrabacher, a Democrat and a Republican, have co-sponsored an amendment to the Department of Justice Appropriations Bill that would prohibit the spending of any money to prosecute patients in states in which medical cannabis is legal.
Well, the last time I believe this measure came up in the House of Representatives, it lost by a--I don't remember the exact margin, but a thumping margin.
It lost by about 70 votes last time.
And while 70 votes is significant, it is not something that cannot be overcome, particularly when you have six justices of the Supreme Court essentially calling on Congress to make that change.
